div1.p: THE BOSTON GLOBE-TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 24, 1925

HIS RACE WITH DEATH WON BY LAST
OF THE YELLOW FEVER PIONEERS

Dr Henry Ross Carter, the Only Man Who Could Write It, Finished
Section 111 of the History of the Dread Disease Only
Three Days Before He Died
By MAYME OBER PEAK

On the rapidly growing roster of
America's great peace heroes, dying
that others might live, was inscribed
recently the name of Dr Henry Ross
Carter, Assistant Surgeon General,
United States Public Health Service.

The last of that matchless com-
pany of pioneers in yellow fever and
malaria work--Lazier, Reed, Carroll,
Gorgas--who will be credited to the
19th century but to whom every age
will be debtor, Dr Carter devoted
all the energy of his spirit for 50
years to ridding the earth of the
dread diseases carried by the mos-
quito.

His passing, at the age of 73, was
as triumphant and heroic as any
chapter in his courageous, conse-
crated life. Though he died as every
man wants to die--surrounded by
his loved ones and at peace with his
Maker, his end was no less dramatic
than that of his comrades in the serv-
ice who at the time were meeting
sudden, tragic deaths in the air above
and in the waters beneath.
Won by Three Days

For two years Dr Carter ran a race
with death, to complete what no other
living man could write--“The History
of Yellow Fever, Its Origin and Con-
trol.” Day and night he faced the
grim reaper, faced him as serenely as
he had braved him in the exuberance
of health when the trail of yellow
fever and malaria led him through
the tropical jungles of Panama, the
oozing swamps of South America, or
the marshes of his native Southland.

Absorbed in the battle, oblivious to
hardships and dangers, caring nothing
for the honors due him, he never came
off the fighting line until his body was
broken, his heart physically weakened.

For three years Dr Carter warded off
complete invalidism, first in crutches
and then in a wheel chair. Even after
this he attended an important scientific
conference in the Tropics, being carried
to and from the ship on a stretcher!
When finally chained to bed, suffering
from severe attacks of angina pectoris,
the real race with death began--a race
won by the narrow margin of three
days.

Battling for breath to dictate Dr Car-
ter's spirit was that of the Roman
general, whom he quoted when advised
to stop work: “It is necessary that I
get to Pelusium; it is not necessary
that I live!”

“And get to Pelusium we did,” said
his daughter, Miss Laura Armstead
Carter, whose unselfish devotion to her
father as collaborator, secretary, com-
panion, comrade, nurse, is one of the
beautiful traditions of the service--
“father, interested, alert, happy and
exalted in his great work of final ser-
vice up to within a few hours of the
heart attack that was the beginning
of the end. I--on black coffee, strychi-
nine, aspirin, and by the Grace of God!
For of course I had to work while he
rested, to transcribe the notes he dic-
tated, doing this late at night or very
early in the morning, as he waked
about 5:30, when we had our early
coffee together and planned the work
for the day.
No One Else Could Have Done It

“Thanks to living only for the work,
we finished Section 111, by a three-day
margin, and father had the satisfac-
tion of knowing that the most impor-
tant part of the book was saved. This
is as far as I will go with it as it
makes a complete entity as it stands.”

When the Rockefeller Foundation
first took up the question of writing
the history of yellow fever with Dr
Carter, chairman of the Yellow Fever
Council of its International Health
Board, he had just returned from 18
months' service as sanitary adviser
to the Peruvian Government. Emaci-
ated by fever, lamed by a dislocated
hip, he realized that he was on his
“last legs” and did not expect to live
long enough to complete the book,
which, ‘involving endless research,
would take at least five years. He
was unwilling to undertake it unless
he could so arrange the work as to
make every piece count by itself--’ like
building a stairway,” he said, “so that
whoever comes after me can go on
from the step at which I left off.”

Thus the book was written. The first
section was finished three years ago,
and mimeographed for the men in the
field for use as a textbook. By the
yellow fever men this section is known
as “The Rockefeller Bible.”

Section 111 is unique. No one else
could have written it. It took a man
with a command of many languages,
ancient and modern, including Latin
as written by the priests at the time
of the conquest of the New World;
the Maya MSS; the Mexican hiero-
glyphics; Portuguese, Spanish, Italian
and French. It took a man, too, with
a broad and strictly accurate historical
background, both for the Old and New
World, as well as one who was a rec-
ognized world authority on yellow
fever, from its epidemiological, clinical
and historical standpoints.
Off for Panama

As long as Dr Carter could get about
on crutches, he was a familiar figure
at the Library of Congress where, day
after day, hour after hour, his iron
gray head could be seen bent over some
massive volume on his desk. After he
was tied to a wheel-chair, the library
came to the doctor.

Running in for a late cup of tea with
the hurrying historian and his faithful
scribe at their Washington apartment,
the writer would find them buried be-
hind a mound of books. The low card-
table on which the doctor worked was
the only oasis in the desert, and this
was littered with notes. On top of the
papers the tea tray would be placed,
and while we teaed and talked, Dr Car-
ter relaxed.

It was on one of the occasions when
he was in a particularly mellow mood
that he told me of his fight with yellow
fever in Panama--one of the most dra-
matic campaigns of his war with the
enemy. As ranking officer next to Gor-
gas, Dr Carter was connected with most
of the organization and early work on
the Isthmus. He organized the quar-
antine service and later served as Di-
rector of Hospitals and chairman of the
Board of Diagnosis.

“We were just three old codgers,” he
chuckled, lifting his eyes to the finely-
chiseled features of “the Chief,”-Gen
Gorgas--framed on the wall, “when we
went down to Panama to clean up.
Gorgas, then colonel, came to me when
he was appointed chief sanitary officer
of the Canal, and asked me to go along.
He said that Rear Admiral Ross, whose
yellow fever work in Cuba dated back

HENRY ROSE CARTER
Late Assistant Surgeon General,
United States Public Health Service

to the momentous days of the Reed
Board, had promised to go if I would,
and that as it would be probably the
last work we old codgers would do,
he thought we ought to go.

“I agreed with him. And we set forth
on the adventure in high spirits. We
reached Panama in June, in extremely
hot weather. It rained four times a
day. When it stopped and the sun
would come out, it was like opening
the door of a furnace.
One Candle for Four Rooms

“We were assigned quarters in an old
building in Ancon. Gorgas, Ross and I
shared the same room, the same bu-
reau. Gorgas had the top drawer, I
the middle drawer, and Ross the bot-
tom. If any guests came, they put
their things on the floor! We hung
our top clothes on the wall, covering
them with a gorgeous flowered curtain
purchased from a Chinaman in Panama.

“The private bath was my trunk,
turned upside down, with bowl and
pitcher on top. The washstand proper
had to be used for a desk. We slept
on cots and had pillows that you blow
up.

“Everybody had to turn in at the
same time at night. There were no
lamps then, and as I was the only one
who had thought to bring candles, they
had to be made to go a long way.
For each of the four sleeping rooms,
occupied by 15 other officers and em-
ployes, the nightly allotment was a
fourth of a candle. No man dared to
go to bed without first killing all the
mosquitoes in his net.

“Galleries ran all round the build-
ing, upstairs and down. We bought
all the wire netting we could find in
Panama and screened off a small por-
tion of the upper gallery, dubbing it
‘the cage.’ Here we sat after dinner,
reviewing the day and enjoying the
soft, cool breezes and the lovely view.

“For the Americans, the poor food
and the lack of ice were the greatest
hardships. There was no water sup-
ply--and thereon hangs the tale of yel-
low fever in Panama!
Fixing Mosquito's Guilt

“The greatest difficulty was in ob-
taining the necessary legal authority to
clean up; the next was to get the neces-
sary sanitary supplies. We personally
had seen to it that several tons of
sulphur, acids, alcohol and sulphur pots
were carried to the New York wharf
of the Panama Steamship Company and
put on the same ship with us, only to
find it tied up in red tape on arrival
that took us months to unwind.

“Ross billed his consignment to the
Isthmian Commission; I billed mine to
myself at LaBoca. He got his in the
Spring by the requisition route. I got
mine by cart, as I could personally
haul it away.

“In the beginning we paid too much
attention to isolating the patient. Hav-
ing proved the responsibility of the
Stegomyia fasciata, as we then called
it, for the carriage of yellow fever, we
know now that there is no danger from
close contact with the patient, even from
sleeping in the same bed with him. The
only danger is from the mosquitoes that
have bitten him!

“Another thing we have proved is that
mosquitoes do not breed in swamps,
mud puddles or street gutters unless
they are lined with something and have
no mud sides. We have formulated that
they do not breed in any collection of
water, the sides of which at the water's
edge are of mud. They do breed in col-
lections of water in artificial containers
and in similar things such as cisterns,
tin pans, water put out for chickens,
to drink, saucers under the legs of
tables to keep the ants off, and so on.

“In Panama the Stegomyia bred in
just these things. There was no city
water supply. Everybody stored water
in their homes in artificial containers.
They saved rain water, or bought from
the aguadores--carriers who got water
from the wells and peddled it through
the streets on the backs of mules.
Dishpan Put Ship in Danger

“A dishpan came very near causing
the death of the personnel of a battle-
ship. Called out of bed one night by an
orderly from the Boston, then in the
harbor, I found on reaching the ship
that six men were ill with the fever,
including the ship's doctor, two officers
and the mess steward. Searching the
ship for the source of the trouble, we
discovered outside the cook's quarters
a dishpan of water that was almost a
soup of wiggletales of Stegomyia.

“On New Year's night we had at-
tended a ‘sing-song’ on board the Bos-
ton. Evidently there had been a walk-
ing case of yellow fever among the
numerous guests. The Stegomyia that
had bitten him were breeding death for
the whole ship!”

“It was difficult for the Panamanians
to get used to our treatment of yellow
fever. Though immune themselves,
having had yellow fever when they
were children, they remembered the
terrible toil it had exacted from the
French, and were horrified at the risks
the Americans took. When Mrs Gorgas
and my family joined us, six months
after arriving on the isthmus, we
shared quarters on the second floor of
an old French building formerly used
as a hospital for the officers of the
French Canal Company. Under us was
the officers' mess, where we all ate
together, and under the chapel where
we had the yellow fever funerals.

“Diagonally across the road was the
yellow fever hospital, the doors and
windows always open. Neither had
glass nor shutters, but were thickly
screened. There were also double
screen doors at the entrance, with a
smudge fire burning between, and an
orderly constantly on duty to keep
them going and to brush off the clothes
of the doctors and nurses as they went
in and out. Also, the patients were in
mosquito-proof cages, so it was really
impossible for Stegomyia to get in and
become infected by them.

“But to the horror of the Pana-
manians, my daughter--the first Ameri-
can girl on the Isthmus, would sit on
the steps of the hospital and wait for
me whenever she felt inclined. ‘You
must wish her to become an angel!’
they protested.
Coffins for All Six

“When an official died with yellow
fever, there was a general panic. If
an Italian laborer died, no notice was
taken of it, though there was as much
danger from one as the other.

“Those who were case-hardened or
educated up to the mosquito theory of
course could joke about it. I remember
when the Isthmian Canal Commission
came to Panama--six in number, the
seventh member being in Paris--one of
the commissioners noticed six metallic
coffins that had been unloaded from
the same ship and laid out on the dock.

“Why the half dozen coffins?” he
asked an official.

“Well, you know Mr Parsons didn't
come,” was the quick reply.

“The commissionerss slept on board
that night and every other night while
in Panama.

“What are the symptoms of yellow
fever?” I once asked Dr Carter.

“Similar to the first stages of acute
alcoholism--red, flushed face, swollen
lips, vomiting, headache. As the tem-
perature rises the pulse falls away from
it. If the two rise and cross, then it
is le nocud fatal--the fatal knot.”

“What is the treatment?” I queried
further.

“It rests upon a tripod. Absolute rest
in bed; complete starvation for a rea-
sonable time, and as much water as
patient can be made to take without
vomiting.”
“Are there any ill effects?”

“Practically none whatever. Yellow
fever has no sequence. The poison
passes rapidly through the system,
either killing the patient in five or
seven days or leaving entirely. There
is little suffering connected with it, save
in the beginning. The victim lies in a
coma or stupor, and is very, very
weak.”
Both Surgeon and Engineer

Dr Carter spoke from experience. Like
his chief, Gen Gorgas, he suffered from
an attack of yellow fever early in the
game. In the Summer of 1897, follow-
ing the campaign in the fever-infected
districts of Louisiana and Mississippi,
he contracted the disease.

“I knew I had it,” he said, “and
spent the first day winding up import-
ant official matters. For days after I
entered the hospital at New Orleans I
was so weak that only when the thirst
became more than I could bear would I
expend enough energy to lift my thumb,
to which a bell was tied, to call the
nurse. I figured it out that since
water was a word of two syllables, it
required less effort to say ‘drink’ and
this was the one mental calculation I
made and the one word I uttered.

“During the Panama campaign, I jolly
well sympathized with one of the pa-
tients who had black water fever. He
insisted upon going home before the
was well enough to leave the hospital.
‘Don't you know you are a mighty weak
man?’ the colonel reminded him.
‘That's just it,’ he replied, ‘let me go
home and get a little strength, and
then I'll come back and you can doctor
me all you please!’”

Dr Carter remained on the Isthmus
five years. For his conspicious service
in connection with the building of the
Canal, Congress created for him the
position of Assistant Surgeon General-
at-Large of the United States Public
Health Service, thus breaking all prece-
dents in recognizing the work of a mem-
ber of that service.

Since the modern viewpoint is that
public health is a problem for engin-
eers rather than doctors, Dr Carter's
accomplishments as a scientific worker
in sanitation is largely due perhaps to
the fact that he was both an engineer
and a doctor. In 1873 has was gradu-
ated from the University of Virginia
as civil and mining engineer, and in
1879 form the University of Maryland
as an M. D. In 1911 this latter univer-
sity conferred upon him the degree of
LL.D.
His List of Achievements

Immediately after he was graduated
in medicine he entered the Marine Hos-
pital Service (now the Public Health
Service). In the Fall of that same year
he saw his first case of yellow fever--
in the epidemic at Memphis, of which
he had charge.

It was at Ship Island Quarantine Sta-
tion, in the Gulf of Mexico, that he had
unique opportunity to study at length
the disease of far-reaching public health
and economic importance, and prevent
its entrance into the country. To this
Federal refuge station came all vessels
infected, or thought to be infected.
Many of them were sailing vessels from
Rio, Santos, Havana and Colon--all
danger zones at that time.

Here on this lonely island, cut off
from communication from the outside
world except by boat call, Dr Carter,
with a young family growing up around
him, practically laid the foundation of
his great work for the control and pre-
vention of yellow fever.

Briefly summarized, his sanitary and
scientific achievements were:

list.item:
1--The determination of the period of
extrinsic incubation of yellow fever
which determined the direction of the
brilliant work of the Reed Commis-
sioner, and for which Dr Carter was
nominated for the Nobel Prize by Sir
Ronald Ross.

2--The founding of the present mari-
time quarantine system of the United
States.

3--The control of numerous yellow
fever epidemics in the Southern States.

4--The inauguration of the quarantine
systems of Cuba and the Canal Zone.

5--The initiation of malaria control in
the United States.

6--The enunciation of principles relat-
ing to the bearing of impounding of
great bodies of water on the production
of malaria, a matter in which the eco-
nomic future of the Southern States is
bound up.

7--The control of malaria during the
late War in the extra-cantonment
areas of the camps and regions around
the big industrial plants engaged in
production of war material.

8--Numerous articles on yellow fever
and malaria, also sections on yellow
fever in several systems of medicine,
published here and abroad.

9--History of yellow fever for the
Rockefeller Foundation.

div1.p: Testament Ever With Him

Seeking the contributing factors to so
remarkable a record, aside from Dr
Carter's natural ability, one finds that
his life of many-sided service was
molded by a woman--his mother. Pos-
sessed of a singularly clear and power-
ful intellect, deeply religious, with def-
inite views as to duty to God and man,
she set her son's feet upon the right
trail and imbued him with the ideals
that kept them there.

As a child Henry Carter was very
delicate. He was well in his teens be-
fore he left home to attend Aspen Hill
Academy. All of his early education
was obtained from his mother and from
private tutors.

When he went out into the world,
a pocket edition of the New Testament
and Psalms was the compass that
guided him on his uncharted course.
Never a morning passed that he did not
read it. So worn was it from constant
use that when he died it was practically
rebound in adhesive plaster!

Henery Carter was born on the Clif-
ton plantation, Caroline County, Va.

It was by the side of his fathers, in
the little cemetery near Ashland, Va,
that Dr Carter was laid to rest. A
special train brought the flag-draped
casket from Washington, accompanied
by a military guard of honor, by his
colleagues in the service, by dignitaries
in official life and men high in the
scientific and medical world, headed by
his two chiefs, Surgeon General Hugh
Cumming of the United States Public
Health Service, and Dr George E. Vin-
cent, chairman of the Rockefeller
Foundation.

As he passed on his way to higher
service between the lines of khaki-clad
men at salute, it was as though he were
again taking the field--not leaving it.
